awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Tetrapyrrole Architectures Displaying a Multielectron Redox Chemistry for CO2 Activation and Energy Catalysis
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Catalysis program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Joel Rosenthal of the University of Delaware will develop new catalyst platforms for the activation and interconversion of small molecule species. Processes that have energy consequences will be targeted. This research will focus on the synthesis and study of new tetrapyrrole complexes with unusual photophysical and multielectron redox properties. These systems will be thoroughly examined by a combination of X-ray crystallography, voltammetry and several types of electronic spectroscopy. Electrochemical and chemical reduction methods will be used to probe the ability of the tetrapyrrole complexes to catalyze the oxygen reduction reaction and the conversion of carbon dioxide to chemical fuels. This CAREER award also supports outreach to improve the accessibility of inorganic chemistry and energy science to high school students via summer research internships at the University of Delaware. The broader impacts of this work include potential societal benefits from the development of inexpensive catalysts that can promote renewable energy conversion and production of fuels from carbon dioxide. Additionally, the project will provide mentorship, education and training of a new generation of individuals in order to prepare them for the scientific and societal challenges of the 21st century. 

This project focuses on the development of new inorganic platforms that can drive chemical transformations that are important for energy storage and conversion. To meet this challenge, new metal complexes that are less expensive and easier to obtain than conventional ones will be prepared, characterized and studied. This research will also demonstrate the ability of these inexpensive molecular platforms to promote the challenging bond making and breaking processes that are required in chemical conversions involving small molecules. Some specific goals include developing catalysts for the conversion of carbon dioxide into fuels.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

Award CHE-1352120 supported work that resulted in the design and synthesis of new tetrapyrrole architectures (the phlorin, biladiene, and isocorrole) containing sp3 hybridized meso-carbons. These non-traditional systems were shown to support multielectron redox and photochemical properties tailored for small molecule activation and energy catalysis. The ability of each of these novel platforms to coordinate multiple different redox active metal centers was also demonstrated to provide new complexes for activation of dioxygen (O2) and carbon dioxide (CO2).

In addition to laying the ground work and disseminating methods to prepare phlorins, biladienes and isocorroles, the physical properties of these novel platforms was also evaluated. Each of the non-traditional tetrapyrrole systems displayed distinct redox and photophysical properties compared to traditional porphyrins, which have been a focus of study for many decades by the chemistry and catalysis communities. The multielectron redox properties of cobalt isocorroles and biladienes were found to be particularly well suited for demanding small molecule activation processes such as the 4e–/4H+ oxygen reduction reaction to generate water, which is a process of technological importance for fuel cell and air-battery energy conversion devices. It was demonstrated that properly designed cobalt isocorrole complexes could support the oxygen reduction reaction with selectivities that are comparable to that of currently employed (and cost prohibitive) platinum-based catalysts. The observation that variations in the isocorrole structure impacted the efficiacy of oxygen reduction catalysis was also important as it points to the potential to further control and enhance small molecule activation processes through development of second generation isocorroles. Related complexes of nickel and palladium supported by multitopic ligands were also studied as electrocatalysts for the reduction of carbon dioxide to fuel precursors and commodity chemicals. The synergistic approach involving tetrapyrrole design and synthesis, physical characterization, catalyst benchmarking, and mechanistic studies have delivered results that can be expected to enhance fundamental knowledge relating to multielectron energy catalysis and small molecule activation. 

In related work, the photochemistry and photophysics of biladiene based tetrapyrroles was shown to be distinct from that of traditional porphyrinoids. Metallated biladiene complexes supported an intriguing triplet photochemistry useful for generation of singlet oxygen that was leveraged to develop new agents of photodynamic therapy. By elaborating the biladiene scaffold through addition of conjugated alkyne groups, biladiene complexes that absorb light that can deeply penetrate epithelial tissues for tumor treatment were realized. Biologically compatible biladiene complexes were synthesized and shown to be promising photochemotherapeutic agents against triple-negative breast cancer cells. These advances spur future efforts to leverage the attractive and tunable photochemical properties of new tetrapyrroles containing sp3 hybridized meso-carbons for photomedical applications.

Broader impacts

Students and teachers at the K-12, undergraduate, and postgraduate levels were impacted by this award. Outreach included programs for K-12 students that involved lab tours, STEM info sessions, and hosting of authentic summer research experiences for five high school students. Outreach was also provided to K-12 teachers through Delaware Teacher's Institute (DTI) series led by the PI in 2016, 2017 & 2019. These DTI series assisted ~25 DE school teachers as they developed new curriculum units for their schools in the areas of sustainability, renewable energy, and materials chemistry. Eleven undergraduate researchers from the University of Delaware were trained during the project period, including one student that completed a senior honors research thesis. Each of the UGs pursued professional or graduate studies in STEM or medical fields after completion of their undergraduate training and three received NSFGRF support for PhD studies in chemistry. Access to electrochemistry, electrochemiluminescence (ECL) and energy catalysis experiments was brought to UD teaching labs through design and fabrication of inexpensive breadboard electrolyzers funded by this award.

This award also supported the training of six PhD and two MS students that completed dissertations. The PI and students delivered 35 seminars and conference presentations involving findings and outreach from this award. A total of 17 publicly available peer reviewed publications were supported by this award, which spurred new collaborations centered on use of non-traditional tetrapyrroles to address problems in energy conversion, and improving human health. All students supported by this award received scientific and research training in multiple areas including organic chemistry, inorganic and organometallic chemistry, homogeneous catalysis, electrochemistry, photochemistry and spectroscopy, as well as additional physical methods for chemical characterization and reaction mechanism studies. All student also received training in professional skills related to technical writing and dissemination of research results via oral and poster presentations.

 


Last Modified: 09/01/2021
Modified by: Joel Rosenthal
